segment.source: The Windows.UI.Composition API gives you access to the composition layer between the framework layer (XAML), and the graphics layer (DirectX).
segment.target: The Windows.UI.Composition API gives you access to the composition layer between the framework layer (XAML), and the graphics layer (DirectX).

segment.source: In Windows 10, significant work was done to create a new unified compositor and rendering engine for all Windows applications, be it desktop or mobile.
segment.target: In Windows 10, significant work was done to create a new unified compositor and rendering engine for all Windows applications, be it desktop or mobile.

segment.source: A result of that work was the unified Composition WinRT API called Windows.UI.Composition that offers access to new lightweight Composition objects along with new Compositor driven Animations and Effects.
segment.target: A result of that work was the unified Composition WinRT API called Windows.UI.Composition that offers access to new lightweight Composition objects along with new Compositor driven Animations and Effects.

segment.source: Windows.UI.Composition is a declarative, Retained-Mode API that can be called from any Universal Windows Platform (UWP) Application to create composition objects, animations and effects directly in an application.
segment.target: Windows.UI.Composition is a declarative, Retained-Mode API that can be called from any Universal Windows Platform (UWP) Application to create composition objects, animations and effects directly in an application.

segment.source: The API is a powerful supplement to existing frameworks such as XAML to give developers of UWP applications a familiar C# surface to add to their application.
segment.target: The API is a powerful supplement to existing frameworks such as XAML to give developers of UWP applications a familiar C# surface to add to their application.

segment.source: These APIs can be used to create DX style framework-less applications.
segment.target: These APIs can be used to create DX style framework-less applications.

segment.source: A XAML developer can “drop down” to the composition layer in C# to do custom work in the composition layer using WinRT to create a “Composition Island” of objects in their XAML application rather than dropping all the way down to the graphics layer and using DirectX and C++ for any custom UI work.
segment.target: A XAML developer can “drop down” to the composition layer in C# to do custom work in the composition layer using WinRT to create a “Composition Island” of objects in their XAML application rather than dropping all the way down to the graphics layer and using DirectX and C++ for any custom UI work.

segment.source: Composition Objects and The Compositor
segment.target: Composition Objects and The Compositor

segment.source: Composition objects are created by the Compositor which acts as a factory for composition objects.
segment.target: Composition objects are created by the Compositor which acts as a factory for composition objects.

segment.source: The compositor can create Visual objects, which allow for the creation of a visual tree structure on which all other features and Composition objects in the API use and build on.
segment.target: The compositor can create Visual objects, which allow for the creation of a visual tree structure on which all other features and Composition objects in the API use and build on.

segment.source: The API allows developers to define and create one or many Visual objects each representing a single node in a Visual tree.
segment.target: The API allows developers to define and create one or many Visual objects each representing a single node in a Visual tree.

segment.source: Visuals can be containers for other Visuals or can host content Visuals.
segment.target: Visuals can be containers for other Visuals or can host content Visuals.

segment.source: The API allows for ease of use by providing a clear set of Visual objects for specific tasks that exist in a hierarchy:
segment.target: The API allows for ease of use by providing a clear set of Visual objects for specific tasks that exist in a hierarchy:

segment.source: Visual – The base object.
segment.target: Visual – The base object.

segment.source: The majority of the properties are here, and inherited by the other Visual objects.
segment.target: The majority of the properties are here, and inherited by the other Visual objects.

segment.source: ContainerVisual – Derives from Visual, and adds the ability to insert child visuals.
segment.target: ContainerVisual – Derives from Visual, and adds the ability to insert child visuals.

segment.source: SpriteVisual – Derives from ContainerVisual, and contains content in the form of images, effects, and swapchains.
segment.target: SpriteVisual – Derives from ContainerVisual, and contains content in the form of images, effects, and swapchains.

segment.source: Compositor – The object factory that manages the relationship between an application and the system compositor process.
segment.target: Compositor – The object factory that manages the relationship between an application and the system compositor process.

segment.source: The compositor is also a factory for a number of other composition objects used to clip or transform visuals in the tree as well as a rich set of animations and effects.
segment.target: The compositor is also a factory for a number of other composition objects used to clip or transform visuals in the tree as well as a rich set of animations and effects.

segment.source: Effects System
segment.target: Effects System

segment.source: Windows.UI.Composition supports real time effects that can be animated, customized and chained.
segment.target: Windows.UI.Composition supports real time effects that can be animated, customized and chained.

segment.source: Effects include 2D affine transforms, arithmetic composites, blends, color source, composite, contrast, exposure, grayscale, gamma transfer, hue rotate, invert, saturate, sepia, temperature and tint.
segment.target: Effects include 2D affine transforms, arithmetic composites, blends, color source, composite, contrast, exposure, grayscale, gamma transfer, hue rotate, invert, saturate, sepia, temperature and tint.

segment.source: For more information, see the Composition Effects overview.
segment.target: For more information, see the Composition Effects overview.

segment.source: Animation System
segment.target: Animation System

segment.source: Windows.UI.Composition contains an expressive, framework agnostic animation system that allows you to set up two types of Animations: key frame animations and expression animations.
segment.target: Windows.UI.Composition contains an expressive, framework agnostic animation system that allows you to set up two types of Animations: key frame animations and expression animations.

segment.source: These are used to move visual objects, drive a transform or a clip, or animate an effect.
segment.target: These are used to move visual objects, drive a transform or a clip, or animate an effect.

segment.source: By running directly in the compositor process, this ensures smoothness and scale, letting you run large numbers of concurrent, unique animations.
segment.target: By running directly in the compositor process, this ensures smoothness and scale, letting you run large numbers of concurrent, unique animations.

segment.source: For more information, see the Composition animations overview.
segment.target: For more information, see the Composition animations overview.

segment.source: XAML Interoperation
segment.target: XAML Interoperation

segment.source: In addition to creating a visual tree from scratch, the Composition API can interoperate with an existing XAML UI using the ElementCompositionPreview class in Windows.UI.Xaml.Hosting.
segment.target: In addition to creating a visual tree from scratch, the Composition API can interoperate with an existing XAML UI using the ElementCompositionPreview class in Windows.UI.Xaml.Hosting.
